title-group.article-title: Effect of blockage ratio on the maximum temperature under the ceiling in tunnel fires

article-meta.aff: 1Shenyang Fire Research Institute of Ministry of Public Security, Shenyang, P. R. China
2State Key Laboratory of Fire Science, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, P. R. China
3School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Shandong University of Technology, Zibo, P. R. China

author-notes.corresp: Liming Li, Shenyang Fire Research Institute, 218–20 Wenda Rd., Huanggu District, Shenyang, Liaoning, 110034, P. R. China. Email: liliming@syfri.cn; liliming@mail.ustc.edu.cn

abstract.p: Tunnel blockage ratio is defined as the ratio of the cross-sectional area of the fire source to that of the tunnel. These fire sources in reality correspond to those that have considerable cross-sectional area such as trains or heavy goods vehicles, which are very common. The effect of tunnel blockage ratio on the maximum temperature under the ceiling in tunnel fires is analyzed using experimental data from three past studies. Results indicate that the maximum temperature decreases with the increase in the blockage ratio for small fires, while it does not vary with the blockage ratio for large fires. Previous models are modified based on above analysis by introducing a factor that accounts for the blockage effect. The modified models are more generally applicable.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The maximum temperature under the ceiling in tunnel fires is an important issue in the area of tunnel fire safety, as the tunnel structure could be damaged when exposed to the relatively high temperature. Knowledge of this maximum temperature could provide meaningful reference to give adequate fire protection to tunnel structure.

Several recent studies focused on this topic and some models have been proposed.1–7 The maximum temperature in tunnel fires is related to several parameters such as fire heat release rate, longitudinal ventilation velocity, and distance from the fire surface (or bottom) to tunnel ceiling. However, as pointed out by Li et al.,8 the fire sources in most of the past studies are either beneath the tunnel floor or negligible compared to tunnel cross-sectional area. Fire sources in practical tunnels always locate above the tunnel floor and obstruct considerable part of the tunnel cross-sectional area, such as heavy goods vehicle (HGV) fire or subway train fire. These fire sources act as a blockage to the longitudinal ventilation while burning. The longitudinal velocity will be locally increased due to this blockage effect at the fire source and downstream.8 This will affect the tunnel fire characteristics such as the burning rate, the smoke flow pattern, and the temperature. It has been already found that the critical velocity decreases with the increase in tunnel blockage ratio, ϕ, which is defined as the ratio of the cross-sectional area of the fire source to the cross-sectional area of the tunnel. However, no studies have considered the effect of tunnel blockage ratio on the maximum temperature under the ceiling in tunnel fires.

Motivated by the past studies, this study will focus on the effect of tunnel blockage ratio on the maximum temperature under the ceiling in tunnel fires. Data from several past studies that conducted experimental fire tests in tunnels with considerable blockage ratios are used. By analyzing these experimental data, previous models will be modified by introducing a factor that accounts for the blockage effect of the fire source. Meanwhile, the upper limit of the maximum temperature is also studied.

sec.title: Models for the maximum temperature
sec.p: Kurioka et al.1 proposed the following empirical model based on a series of tunnel fire tests

This is the first time that a model was proposed for the maximum temperature in tunnel fires. As shown, when the fire is relatively small, the maximum temperature increases with the 4/5 power of the fire heat release rate, while it decreases with the 4/5 power of the longitudinal ventilation velocity. However, when the fire is relatively large, the maximum temperature does not vary with these two parameters. The reason for the piecewise dependence will be discussed later. The Kurioka model has been verified by the full-scale tunnel fire tests from Hu et al.2 and Wang et al.9 and the reduced-scale tunnel fire tests from Yuan et al.10 However, note that those experimental data only confirmed the first piece of Kurioka model.

Zhao et al.4 analyzed numerically the validity of equation (1). They found that equation (1) is feasible under the following conditions: (a) longitudinal ventilation velocity bigger than 0.8 m/s, (b) fire heat release rate smaller than 35 MW, and (c) distance from fire surface to tunnel ceiling within 4.5–8 m. Based on the numerical results, Zhao et al.4 modified Kurioka model as follows

Note that equation (2) is completely based on numerical analysis and no experimental validation has been carried out. Yi et al.5 studied the effect of tunnel slope on the maximum temperature using a reduced-scale tunnel model. They found that the maximum temperature decreases with the increase in tunnel slope. Yi et al.5 proposed a slope correction factor, ks, to modify Kurioka model as

Li et al.6 found that Kurioka model would give an infinite estimation of the maximum temperature when the longitudinal ventilation approaches zero, which is not physically explainable. Thus, Li et al.6 presented a theoretical analysis based on an axisymmetric fire plume theory and conducted a series of reduced-scale tunnel fire tests. The following correlation was proposed
where the dimensionless ventilation velocity was given as

Equation (4) shows better estimations compared to Kurioka model, especially when the longitudinal ventilation is small.6 However, it is applicable to only small fire cases where the flame does not contact with the tunnel ceiling. Li and Ingason11 further analyzed experimental data from previous studies and improved the above model to obtain the following

In summary, the maximum temperature in the tunnel fires shows a piecewise dependence on the combination of relevant parameters where it increases to an end point (upper limit) and then keeps constant at the upper limit. Most studies focused on the increasing part of this dependence but did not include the effect of tunnel blockage ratio, while one study proposed the upper limit that is too small compared to the following experimental data from several recent tunnel fire tests. The following parts of this article will try to include the tunnel blockage effect and fix the upper limit in the models.

sec.title: Experimental data
sec.p: Experimental data ranging from reduced-scale to full-scale tunnel fire tests are employed, which are from Ingason and Li,12 Kayili et al.,13 and the Runehamar tunnel fire tests.14 The Froude scaling that is based on the preservation of Froude number is adopted.8,12,13,15

The most recent study by Kayili et al.13 carried out tunnel fire tests using a 1/13 reduced-scale tunnel model. The tunnel model was 6.5 m long, 0.4 m wide, and 0.364 m high with an arched ceiling, as shown in Figure 1. Wood cribs with different configurations were used as fire sources, which produced blockage ratios ranging from 0.093 to 0.561. The same calculation of blockage ratio as used by Kayili et al., that is, the maximum blockage ratio, is adopted, as shown in Figure 1. The smoke temperature under the tunnel ceiling was monitored by 0.5-mm K-type thermocouples. The maximum temperatures were obtained from these thermocouple readings. The height and width of the fire sources and corresponding blockage ratios, fire heat release rates, longitudinal ventilation velocities, and the maximum temperatures are listed in Table 1.

caption.p: Configuration of the tunnel model used by Kayili et al.13 The right subfigure shows the calculation of tunnel blockage ratio.
Experimental data from Kayili et al.13

sec.p: Ingason and Li12 conducted 12 tunnel fire tests under various longitudinal ventilations with two 1/23 reduced-scale tunnel models. The tunnels were 10 m long, 0.4 m wide with the heights of 0.3 and 0.2 m for Tunnels A and B, respectively. Wood cribs with two different scales were used, which produced a blockage ratio of 0.1715 and 0.1575, respectively, for Tunnels A and B. The temperature was measured using 0.25-mm K-type thermocouples. The longitudinal ventilation velocity, the maximum fire heat release rate and corresponding maximum temperature are listed in the article by Ingason and Li.12

Runehamar tunnel fire tests were conducted in a discarded road tunnel that was 9 m wide and 6 m high with an arched ceiling. Four tests were performed with HGV cargos as fire sources. The HGV setup was 10.5 m long, 2.9 m wide, and 3.3 m high, which was placed on a platform 1.1 m above the road surface. The HGV cargo acted as a blockage to the longitudinal ventilation while burning, which produced a blockage ratio of approximately 0.218. The longitudinal ventilation was approximately 3 m/s. The results of Runehamar tunnel fire tests are summarized in Table 2.

caption.p: Full-scale experimental data from Runehamar tunnel fire tests14

sec.p: All the tunnels are horizontal without any slopes, and all the ventilation velocities are greater than 0.8 m/s after scaling. Thus, in the following analysis, no attentions are put into the effect of tunnel slope or the ventilation velocity.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Data from Kayili et al.13 are first used to examine the Kurioka model for the maximum temperature in tunnel fires, as they contain the most blockage ratio considerations. These data are plotted in Figure 2 using the variables defined in equation (1), as seen in the abscissa and ordinate. Figure 2 shows that tunnel blockage ratio does have some effect on the maximum temperature under tunnel ceiling. In general, the Kurioka model overestimates all the data shown in Figure 2; the maximum temperature decreases with the increase in blockage ratio. The possible reasons for this are as follows.

caption.p: Effect of tunnel blockage ratio on the maximum temperature under tunnel ceiling.
Source: Experimental data are from Kayili et al.13

sec.p: Figure 2 shows the first piece of the Kurioka model where the maximum temperature depends on the fire heat release rate and longitudinal ventilation. This part usually corresponds to small fire cases where the fire flame does not impinge on tunnel ceiling. In these cases, the maximum temperature mainly comes from the fire smoke temperature that is strongly determined by the fire heat release rate and tunnel ventilation condition. When the fire source occupies part of the tunnel cross-sectional area, the longitudinal velocity is locally increased at the fire and downstream, and bigger blockage induces larger velocity increment.8 Affected by the increased ventilation velocity, the discharge rate of fire smoke in the tunnel is accelerated, and the ability of the ventilation to take away the heat generated by the fire is increased, therefore causing the reduction of the maximum temperature of the fire smoke.

Figure 3 compares all the data considered here to the Kurioka model. Data from the full-scale tunnel fire tests by Kurioka et al.1 themselves are also included, that is, those from Tunnels D and E. Except those phenomena found in Figure 2, the first piece of the Kurioka model also overestimates their own experimental data that do not have any blockages. On the other hand, the latter piece of the Kurioka model underestimates the reduced-scale experimental results from Ingason and Li12 and the full-scale experimental results from the Runehamar tunnel fire tests. 14

caption.p: Comparison between the Kurioka model and the experimental data considered in this study.

sec.p: It is found that the maximum temperature from the full-scale Runehamar tunnel fire tests14 and the reduced-scale tunnel fire tests12 varies with neither fire heat release rate or longitudinal ventilation nor tunnel blockage ratio. Kurioka et al.1 also found that the maximum temperature rise ΔTmax/Ta increases with quantity Q*2/3/Fr1/3 to an upper limit and then keeps constant at this upper limit. This could be physically explained as follows. The two series of tunnel fire tests considered here12,14 and some cases in Kurioka et al.’s study correspond to those large tunnel fires where the fire flame contacts with tunnel ceiling. In these cases, the maximum temperature under tunnel ceiling mainly comes from the intermittent or continuous flame region of the fire. The flame temperature depends on the combustion itself and the initial temperature and pressure, which is independent of fire heat release rate and tunnel ventilation condition as well as blockage ratio. This gives a basic explanation of the piecewise dependence of ΔTmax/Ta on Q*2/3/Fr1/3 in the Kurioka model. Although Kurioka et al.1 proposed the model in equation (1), which is the most accepted, they did not provide any discussion on the piecewise dependence phenomena.

Based on the experimental results, Kurioka et al. took the upper limit for the maximum excess temperature as 770 K, which induced the latter piece of the Kurioka model in equation (1). However, it is noticed that the maximum excess temperatures from Ingason and Li’s12 study and Runehamar tunnel fire tests14 were over 1000 K. This means that the latter piece of the Kurioka model underestimates the maximum temperature under tunnel ceiling, whether tunnel blockage ratio is considered or not. This restricts the application of Kurioka model to large tunnel fires and explains the last two restrictions that were pointed out by Zhao et al.4 This upper limit will be modified while considering the blockage ratio effect in the following.

Rearranging equation (1) reveals the term ΔTmax/Ta/[Q*2/3/Fr1/3]6/5, which is plotted against the factor (1 −ϕ) that represents tunnel blockage effect, as shown in Figure 4. The fit in Figure 4 shows the following correlation
which comes to

caption.p: Effect of the factor (1 −ϕ) on Kurioka model.
Source: Experimental data are from Kayili et al.13

sec.p: With the above correlation, data in Figures 2 and 3 are reanalyzed in Figures 5 and 6. It is seen that data from different blockage ratios correlate to each other well and reveal a better fit than Kurioka model. After introducing the factor (1 −ϕ)5/2 to the right-hand side of equation (1), data with various blockage ratios from tunnels with different scales correlate to each other very well. The piecewise fit in Figure 6 reveals a correlation coefficient of R2 = 0.92 and a model for the maximum temperature in tunnel fires

caption.p: Comparison between the modified Kurioka model and the experimental data from Kayili et al.13 that include various blockage ratios.
Comparison between the modified Kurioka model and the experimental data considered in this study.

sec.p: Equation (8) is further examined using the most famous full-scale tunnel fire tests. Those tests are summarized in Table 3 that shows the name of these test series, fire sources, area of tunnel cross section, tunnel height, longitudinal ventilation velocity, and the maximum heat release rate in the test. In those fire tests in Table 3, the cross-sectional area of the fire source is negligible compared to tunnel cross-sectional area, thus the blockage ratio is taken as zero here. Experimental data from those fire tests are compared with the model in equation (8) as shown in Figure 7. The main scatters are from the data of project EUREKA EU499.17 The possible reason is that there was water leaking out of the tunnel walls in the tests, which caused the relative humidity to be as high as around 100%. This has a cooling effect on the fire gases further away from the fire source. The comparison results of the constant part are shown in Figure 8. The dashed lines are the ±15% relative error lines. It is seen that most of the test points locate within the two dashed lines, which shows the accuracy of the maximum temperature predictions by the model in this article.

caption.p: Summary of full-scale tunnel fire tests that do not have blockage ratio

tr.td: Lemaire et al., 21 Lemaire and Kenyon 22

caption.p: Comparison with other famous full-scale tunnel fire experimental data.
The maximum excess ceiling temperature in the constant part of the modified Kurioka model.

sec.p: Equation (8) modifies the Kurioka model by introducing a factor (1 −ϕ)5/2 that represents the effect of tunnel blockage ratio. As discussed, the modified model from this article could not only accounts for the tunnel blockage effect but also shows better estimation on the maximum temperature, especially for large tunnel fire scenarios.

With the same manner, the maximum smoke temperature model from Li et al.11 in equation (5) is examined using the data from Kayili et al.,13 as shown in Figure 9. With air properties and the approximation of Qc = 0.7Q, the values of U′ in equation (5) for all the data in Table 1 are greater than 0.19. The fit in Figure 9 reveals the following correlation

caption.p: Effect of the factor (1 −ϕ) on the model by Li et al.11
Source: Experimental data are from Kayili et al.13

sec.p: Figure 10 compares the modified model in equation (9) with the data from Ingason and Li.,12 Kayili et al.,13 and Runehamar tunnel fire tests.14 The result shows a good agreement between the experimental data and the model predictions and reveals a correlation coefficient of R2 = 0.81. Comparison with the data in Table 3 that have no tunnel blockages in the test has already been conducted by Li et al.,11 which is not repeated here.

caption.p: Comparison between the modified model of Li et al.11 and the experimental data from Kayili et al.13

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: The blockage effect of fire source on the maximum temperature in tunnel fires was analyzed. For small fires where the flame does not impinge on the tunnel ceiling, the maximum temperature mainly comes from the fire smoke, which decreases with the increase in tunnel blockage ratio, as the blockage of fire source changes the local ventilation condition. However, for large fires where the flame contacts with the tunnel ceiling, the maximum temperature mainly comes from the fire flame that is independent of tunnel ventilation condition. Therefore, the maximum temperature is not affected by tunnel blockage ratio. From this analysis, it is concluded that the thermal protection for a nonobstructed tunnel in practical applications is sufficient to protect the structure in a corresponding tunnel that has blockage.

The best known Kurioka model was modified by introducing the factor (1 −ϕ)5/2 that represents tunnel blockage effect; the upper limit for large fires in Kurioka model was also modified by the data from existed tunnel fire tests. The modified model could give better estimations of the maximum temperature while considering tunnel blockage effect. Also, the maximum smoke temperature model by Li et al. was modified by a factor (1 −ϕ)4/3.
